messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] thoughts on Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: One wonders if any Satsuma-to are featured in the Satsuma Koshirae catalog or if we find Mito tsuba on the swords of Omura Kaboku. I think what happened was
messages.messageBody:
One wonders if any Satsuma-to are featured in the Satsuma Koshirae
catalog or if we find Mito tsuba on the swords of Omura Kaboku. I think
what happened was that when a lord did Sankin-kotai and he liked to
show off, he would outfit his guys in matching koshirae. Adding some
new innovation or regional specialty would add kick. Done right these
styles would become popular with the residents of Edo and then spread
to other provinces. Thus we see Higo style stuff from other places, at
the same time Higo enjoyed a thriving business...
-t

messages.subject: thoughts on Koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Is there a preference for koshirae for certain schools of swords. To clarify, I have a certain feeling that I should see or at least expect to see Hizen blades
messages.messageBody:
Is there a preference for koshirae for certain schools of swords. To
clarify, I have a certain feeling that I should see or at least
expect to see Hizen blades in Higo koshirae. They seen to fit for
some reason unbeknownst to me.
So is there a school of koshirae that is more suited to say Yamashiro
blades, or swords of the Echizen province and things like that or is
it more just the taste of the owner.

I was thinking that a sword from say Iwami province probably wouldn't
have Edo koshirae or Higo for that matter as they would be to far
away and the owner would select a local or more local artisan unless
they traveled or were of a higher stature and had no budget
constraints.

any thoughts on this ??

cheers

Rich
